WWF (World Wide Fund for Nature) is an international environmental organization founded in 1961. WWF's aim is to stop the deterioration of the environment and build a future where humanity lives in harmony with nature. At first, WWF focused on protecting endangered species such as tigers and polar bears, but since the 1980s, it has invested more in solving global environmental problems. WWF strives to influence the development of environmental legislation in different countries and the conclusion of international agreements, for example limiting emissions. The international president of WWF has been Yolanda Kakabadse from Ecuador since 2010, whose predecessor was Emeka Anyaoku. Liisa Rohweder has been the Secretary General of WWF Finland since 2009. Money ("L'argent") is a 1983 French film directed by Robert Bresson. It was Bresson's last film and was loosely based on Leo Tolstoy's short story "The Counterfeit Interest Ticket". The central character of "Money" is Yvon Targe (Christian Patey), who gets his hands on a fake banknote that has already been circulating among a few people. He doesn't know the money is counterfeit, tries to pay for his purchases with it and ends up in jail. As a result, he loses his job and drifts into crime. Yvon goes to prison again, and while there his child dies of strep throat and his wife leaves him. Yvon loses his mind and, in his freedom, commits a cold-blooded murder. Bresson won the best director award at the Cannes Film Festival for the film. "Money" was chosen by the critics of "The New York Times" in 2004

split_passages_en: The Supercup is a ball sports competition where the champion of the previous season's national series and the cup winner usually meet. Supercup matches are played especially in football, where they are traditional opening events of the new season. Supercups can also be organized by federations of different continents. Then the winners of the competitions organized by the continental association will face each other. The world's most famous and prestigious Supercup is the FA Community Shield played in England, which has been organized since the 1908–1909 season. The winners of the Premier League and the FA Cup currently meet there. Another well-known soccer Supercup is the UEFA Super Cup, organized by the European Football Association since 1972, where the Champions League and Europa League champions play against each other. Other continental football confederations also have their own supercups. The football supercup is not played in Finland.

The Football Association Challenge Cup or FA Cup is an English football tournament, also known in Finnish as the English cup. The FA Cup is the oldest football tournament in the world. It was first held in 1872, when the winner was Wanderers. Since then, similar cup-shaped competitions have started to be organized in other countries as well. The Cup is played in its entirety as playoffs and the match pairs are drawn, although the qualifying round is played regionally so that the travel costs of small clubs do not increase too much. The first and second rounds were previously divided into northern and southern match pairs, but this was abandoned after the 1997–1998 season. The home team is decided by a draw. When the match ends in a draw, the rematch is played on the away team's field. League Cup () is an English cup-shaped football competition organized by the Football League. The League Cup has been organized every year since the 1960–1961 season. Liverpool has won the most championships, with eight championships. For sponsorship reasons, the competition is also known as the Carabao Cup. Unlike England's other major cup tournament, the FA Cup, the League Cup is only open to teams from the Premier League and the three divisions of the English Football League. The winning team of the League Cup gets the right to participate in the 3rd qualifying round of the Europa League.

London's Wembley Stadium, but due to renovations between 2001 and 2006, the match was played at the Millennium Stadium in Cardiff, Wales, which was the first time the final was played outside of England. split_passages_en: Cirrhosis is irreversible liver damage, advanced liver fibrosis, usually caused by excessive alcohol consumption or hepatitis. Although cirrhosis is incurable, its progression can be slowed in the early stages or it can be stopped completely. Sometimes cirrhosis requires a liver transplant. The disease is asymptomatic in the early stages (with the exception of the yellowing eyes of a drunkard) and later causes chronic fatigue and yellowing of the skin in the final stages. Liver transplantation is risky for older cirrhotic patients (over 65 years of age) and is therefore usually not performed in the scope of public medical care. In private hospitals, it is an expensive procedure that requires a long waiting time. For cultural reasons, cirrhosis is primarily a men's disease. However, women seem to be more prone to cirrhosis than men. Age and overweight are risk factors that worsen the disease. People die from cirrhosis in Finland every year

Liposarcoma is a type of soft tissue sarcoma that originates from fat cells. It is the most common soft tissue sarcoma in adults. The tumor is usually painless and slow growing, but in some cases it grows quickly and can ulcerate early. Usually, liposarcoma does not develop from a previous lipoma. In the United States, people who get liposarcoma are on average 50 years old. There, less than 20% of all soft tissue sarcomas are liposarcomas, only less than 5% in children. Internationally, the annual incidence of the disease is 2.5 cases per million people. The most likely locations for the tumor are the torso and lower limbs. Metastases most commonly develop in the lungs and liver. Like other soft tissue sarcomas, liposarcoma is primarily treated surgically. Half of liposarcomas are well differentiated, and in these cases the five-year survival prognosis is 100

Antestor is a Norwegian extreme metal band formed in Jessheim in 1990. Antestor is one of Norway's earliest Christian extreme metal bands, and is said to have started the Christian extreme metal circuit throughout Northern Europe with their demo "The Defeat of Satan" in 1991. Previously, the band called its music style as "sorrow metal" (), because its Christian ideology did not fit black metal, which, especially in Norway, was often publicly associated with Satan worship. Antestor is widely known for being the only Christian black metal band to have a record deal with the UK's Cacophonous Records - one of the major black metal labels that have released albums by bands such as Cradle of Filth, Dimmu Borgir and Sigh.

All the greatest playwrights participated in play competitions, where the best play was awarded. Like tragedy, comedy also originated from rituals held in honor of Dionysus. In Athens, comedies became an official part of the festivities in 486 BC, and the best Comedies were also awarded in drama competitions. Only a few works by the greatest comedy writers have survived. Among the earliest authors, only Aristophanes has survived a few plays, more precisely 11 plays. Comedians ridiculed all persons and institutions; among others, Aristophanes criticized the Athenian democracy in "Birds", the philosopher Socrates in "Clouds", and the Peloponnesian war in "Lysistrates".

This has been explained, among other things, by the fact that Mycenaean literature was transmitted orally, like epic poetry, or that it was written for the wealthier, on finer material that has not survived to modern times. split_passages_en: The Kingdom of Bhutan or Bhutan [butan] is a small inland country in the Himalayas between India and China. Bhutan stretches from the subtropical lowlands to the Himalayan mountains, and the height differences between different parts of the country are up to more than 7,000 meters. Bhutan's economy is based on agriculture and livestock, but forestry, hydropower, tourism and development aid also play an important role in the country's economy. Estimates of the country's population have been revised from more than two million to around 660,000. The capital and largest city of Bhutan is Thimphu. Bhutan is one of the most isolated countries in the world, as the government regulates foreign influence and tourism in order to preserve the country's Buddhist-based culture. Most Buddhists in Bhutan follow the Drukpa Kagyu or Nyingmapa school of Tibetan Buddhism. The official language of the country is Dzongkha

The National Library and Archives of Bhutan (, NLAB) is a government agency operating in Thimphu, the capital of Bhutan, performing the duties of the National Library and Archives of the Kingdom. It operates under the Ministry of Home Affairs and Culture () of Bhutan. The main tasks of the National Library include collecting, maintaining and storing written and otherwise published material published in Bhutan and about the country. Dorji Norbu has been in charge of the National Library and Archives since 2016. At the beginning of 2018, the collections of the National Library and Archives of Bhutan included about 338,950 items: manuscripts, books of Mahayana Buddhism, books, writings and wooden plates (frames) for printing traditional religious books. The oldest titles in the collection include, for example, thirty manuscripts written in gold from the 13th century and the decree of Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyel from 1645. Archiving saves

the court is the Royal Supreme Court of Bhutan. Bhutan's legal system is superficially based on Indian law and the British "common law" system, but in practice is very liberal. The king decides on appointments to the judiciary. According to a report by the Center for European Studies, Bhutan has introduced a happiness index to justify the oppression of minorities to create a national identity and to divert attention from the government's failure to raise the country's poor living standards. Bhutan has criminalized "anti-state" activity, such as criticizing the king or collaborating with exiled activists. Bhutan has been accused of torture, unnecessary arrests and similar human rights violations against ethnic Nepalese and Maoists. Bhutan has arrested peaceful pro-democracy protesters. The government blocked access to two Bhutanese news websites after they criticized the king's uncle's policies as a minister.

However, after Bhutan became a member of the UN in 1971, its government defied India by recognizing Bangladesh. In 1974, Bhutan's foreign minister said that India's "guidance" in the 1949 agreement did not necessarily mean Bhutan was obedient. Bhutan has managed its foreign relations regularly without India's intervention. Bhutan's head of state is the "Druk gyalpo" (dragon king), today Jigme Khesar Namgyal Wangchuck. Although the position is hereditary, the king can be deposed by a two-thirds majority of Parliament ("Tshogdu"). Parliament is bicameral. Asmara is located at an altitude of 2,325 meters (2,347 m according to another source) in the northern corner of the Ethiopian highlands. Greenland (in Greenlandic "Kalaallit Nunaat", in Danish "Grønland") is an autonomous region belonging to Denmark and the world's largest island between the North Atlantic and the Arctic Ocean. Geographically, Greenland belongs to North America, administratively it is an autonomous part of Denmark. The official language is the Greenlandic language, which belongs to the Inuit languages. Most of Greenland's surface area of ​​more than two million square kilometers is covered by glaciers. The island's approximately 57,000 inhabitants are concentrated in an ice-free area of ​​350,000 square kilometers, which can even be used for farming. Fishing and hunting have always been important livelihoods in Greenland. Both the Inuit and the Scandinavians have lived in Greenland since approximately the 11th century. The Scandinavian settlement disappeared at the beginning of the 15th century and was reborn in the 18th century. When Norway separated from Denmark, the territories of Greenland remained in Denmark. Self-government of the island

The special features of Greenland's geography are the island's large surface area and northern location: Greenland is the world's largest island, and it is located between the Arctic Ocean and the North Atlantic. Denmark has ruled Greenland since 1721. Greenland is largely covered by continental ice. The surface area of ​​the island is 2,175,600 square kilometers, of which the ice-free area is 375,600 square kilometers. According to another source, the surface area is 2,166,086 square kilometers and the ice-free area is 410,449 square kilometers. Ice covers 1.7 million square kilometers, or about 80 percent of the surface area. There are many islands along the coast. The area of ​​Greenland is located at approximately latitudes 59–84° N, so the southern part of the island is at the same latitude as Finland. The northernmost point of Greenland is Cape

split_passages_en: Japan (or "Nippon", officially 日本国, "Nihon koku" or "Nippon koku") is an island nation in the Pacific Ocean in East Asia. It is located to the east of China, the Korean Peninsula and Russia, stretching from the Sea of ​​Okhotsk in the north to the East China Sea in the south. The characters that make up the country's name mean "root of the sun" or "source of the sun", which is why Japan is sometimes called the "Land of the Rising Sun". The capital and largest population center of Japan is Tokyo. Japan consists of more than 3,000 islands, the largest of which are Honshū, Hokkaidō, Kyūshū and Shikoku. Most of the islands are mountainous and many are also volcanic; for example, Japan's highest mountain peak, Fuji, is a volcano. The country's population is the tenth largest in the world, more than 127 million people. The Greater Tokyo area, which includes the city of Tokyo and

Thus, the Japanese believed that the emperor was of divine descent. In 1945, Emperor Hirohito was forced by the pressure of the allies to issue a declaration stating that the emperor was not "akitsumikami" (現御神), which the occupying power accepted as a rejection of divinity, but whether this really meant the rejection of the concept of "arahitogami" (現人神) and divine descent has been debated . The most about Amaterasu is told in the national epic "Kojiki", which presents Japanese beliefs and folk tales. Amaterasu is generally believed to be female, but some scholars consider her to be male, as despite everything, the "Kojiki" and other writings do not reveal her gender. In Shinto, Amaterasu is honored in an annual celebration held on July 17.

Japanese mythology refers to the deities, legends and beliefs of the ancient Japanese people. The oldest and most important book about Japanese mythology is "Kojiki", which has been collecting Japanese folk tales for centuries. Another significant work containing Japanese beliefs is "Nihonshoki". After Buddhism, Confucianism and Taoism spread to Japan, the deity lost most of its meaning. However, Shintoism contains several influences inherited from it; among others, Shinto gods were originally worshiped in Japanese mythology. One of the most significant beliefs of the Japanese pantheon was the ancient myth that the Japanese imperial family was descended from the sun goddess Amaterasu. It wasn't until 1945 that Emperor Hirohito, at the insistence of the Allies, had to admit that he was not of divine descent. "Izanagi" (male) and "Izanami" (female), whose first children, "Hiruko" (child of water)

Hana matsuri ( tai ) is a Japanese flower festival celebrating Buddha's birthday. The celebration is celebrated on April 8 and is not a national holiday. The day is spent in temples pouring sweet tea or amacha over the Buddha statue on the altar decorated with flowers with a small ladle. The nature of the celebration varies from place to place. "Kanbutsu-e" and "hana matsuri" were mixed together in the Meiji period, and since then Buddha's birthday has been known as hana matsuri. It is said that when the Buddha was born, one to nine dragons poured pure, fragrant water over him. Another belief related to the original hana matsuri is that in the spring the god came down from the mountains to protect the rice fields and in the fall he ascended the mountains to protect them. Hana matsuri was celebrated to welcome the god.

The artificial ice rink, which was originally located at the site of the ice rink, was completed in 1963 and was the fifth in the series in Finland. At that time, the area still belonged to Lauritsala township. The ice rink was completed in 1972, when the artificial ice rink was covered. Finland's first artificial ice rink. It was built by the city of Tampere, the players of the local hockey clubs and the neighboring soft drink factory Pyynikki Oy, whose refrigeration equipment took care of freezing the rink. Tekojää has been said to have played a decisive role in the professionalization of ice hockey as a whole in Finland, as playing and training opportunities increased as the season went on and the ice reliability improved. Over the years, the field was visited by several foreign teams. The visits of the Canadian and Soviet national teams gathered more than 10,000 spectators in the stands. When the strong Tampere teams Ilves, KOOVEE and Tappara moved to the Hakametsä ice hall, which was completed in 1965, the teams playing at lower league levels stayed at Koulukatu. Today, when several ice rinks have been built in Tampere, the rink on Koulukatu is mainly used for public skating and as a venue for sports classes at nearby schools. Fresh events

Tapiola sports hall is located in Tapiola, Espoo. Among the main league level sports teams, the basketball team Espoo United and the floorball club Esport Oilers play their home games in the hall. The hall also serves as a space for enthusiasts of other sports. The hall also has a gym. The sports hall's grandstand has 1570 seats and 1070 standing places.

Tapiola sports park is a sports park located in Tapiola, Espoo, where there are several sports halls and football fields, as well as a multipurpose hall, Espoo Metro Areena. In 2017, the Urheilupuisto metro station was opened. The sports park has a football stadium, which was opened in 1970. The stadium serves as the home ground of FC Honga, which plays in the First Division. There are also many other football fields in the area of ​​Tapiola sports park that are used for training and matches. The fields are based on sand, artificial grass and natural grass. There are two sports halls owned by Esport in the sports park. The oldest of these, the Esport Center, was completed in 1981. The halls offer a hobby opportunity for many indoor ball sports enthusiasts. Espoo Metro Areena, a multipurpose hall located in the sports park, was completed in 1999. The hall previously served as the home arena of the ice hockey club Espoo Blues. The hall also hosts other sports events and concerts. Hall in ice hockey matches

Jesus' fasting, competition and struggle against the Devil are recurring themes. The image of Jesus in Islam has been influenced by the ascetic tradition of Syrian and Egyptian Christianity. Islam is suspicious of asceticism. Prophet Muhammad took many wives, and during the nights of the fasting month of Ramadan, it is the duty of every Muslim to eat. Jesus' asceticism can also be seen in his distrust of property, the rich and rulers. Islam has a much more favorable attitude towards property than Christianity, because according to tradition, the prophet Muhammad already worked as a merchant. Jesus' values ​​differ from those of the prophet Muhammad, but despite this, Islamic literature has preserved Jesus as an ascetic and unmarried

mention. Muslims believe that God revealed his word to mankind through Muhammad and the earlier prophets of Islam. Muhammad is understood as the "Seal of the Prophets" whose divine revelation was given to mankind in its final form in the Qur'an. Islam sees Judaism and Christianity as "religions of the book" derived from the teachings of the prophets. However, Christians and Jews are considered to have distorted the original message of the prophets (Islam) and thus corrupted the properly understood monotheistic message. Islam is partly based on the same principles as Judaism and Christianity, but there are also significant differences between the three Abrahamic world religions. For example, Islam differs significantly from Christianity in that it is a law-oriented religion, where religious law has traditionally always also meant social or state law, and

the creator of Islamism was the Indian, later Pakistani lawyer Sayyid Abul Ala Maududi (1903–1979), whose writings largely dealt with sharia, governance and human rights. He founded the Jamaat-e-Islami party in 1941 and was its leader until 1972. Maududi advocated the transformation of Islamic Pakistan into one governed by Sharia as interpreted by Shura courts. His most influential work was "Risalat Diniyat". Maududi's ideas influenced the Muslim Brotherhood, which was founded as a critique of liberal Islam in Egypt at the beginning of the 20th century. Alpha Centauri ("α Cen" or "α Centauri", Finnish also Alfa Centauri) is the brightest star in the Centauri constellation and the third brightest star in the night sky, and at the same time the closest alien star system to the Solar System, 4.36 light-years (1.34 pc) away. Alpha Centauri is not a single star, but a binary star consisting of the sun-like, yellow Alpha Centauri A and the smaller, orange Alpha Centauri B. Alpha Centauri A has an apparent magnitude of −0.01 and B has an apparent magnitude of 1.33. The star system also has a possible third component, the red dwarf star Proxima Centauri, which is not necessarily gravitationally bound to orbit the other two stars. The Little Horse (Latin "Equuleus", genitive "Equulei") is the second smallest constellation in the sky after the Southern Cross. It is bounded by Pegasus in the east, Dolphin in the west and Aquarius in the south. The Greek Hipparchus is thought to have invented this constellation in the second century BC. The little horse does not contain bright stars or nebulous deep sky objects that are fixed for the enthusiast. Instead, the constellation has some interesting binary stars: Gamma (γ) Equulei consists of 4.7 and 11.6 magnitude components spaced 2 arcseconds apart. Islam is divided into two main groups: Sunnism and Shiaism. The majority, 85–90 percent, of Muslims are Sunni. In addition to the Koran, Sunnism is based on collections of hadith traditions. Together, they form the prophet Muhammad's way of life, i.e. the Sunnah, on the orthodox tracing of which Sunnism is based. According to the traditional view, the division into Sunnis and Shiites is a reversal of the controversy surrounding the succession of the Prophet Muhammad. In the traditional view, the Sunnis unanimously elected Abu Bakr as the first caliph in 632. After his death, Umar was elected as caliph in 634, and after him, Uthman became the third caliph. Due to the political nature of traditional Islam, there are quite a few secular Muslim-populated states where religion and state are separated. Islam ('submission'; old name Mohammedanism) is a monotheistic Abrahamic religion. According to Islamic tradition, Islam originated in the Arabian Peninsula based on the revelations of the prophet Muhammad in 610. Literally, Islam means submission (to God). In Islam, religious law ("Sharia") plays a central role. The number of Muslims is estimated at 1.7 billion people in 2014. The Islamic world stretches from the west coast of Africa to Indonesia and from Central Asia to the south of the Sahara. Only one in five Muslims speak Arabic as their mother tongue. Yet the Arabic-speaking world has retained spiritual leadership in the interpretation of Islam – with the exception of Shiite Iran. In terms of numbers, there are the most Muslims in Indonesia. Islam is the world's second largest and fastest growing religion. The following information is according to the major trend of Islam, Sunnism, unless otherwise stated

Islam sees Judaism and Christianity as "religions of the book" derived from the teachings of the prophets. However, Christians and Jews are considered to have distorted the original message of the prophets (Islam) and thus corrupted the properly understood monotheistic message. Islam is partly based on the same principles as Judaism and Christianity, but there are also significant differences between the three Abrahamic world religions. split_passages_en: The sperm tube is the tube that grows from the pollen particle of the seed plant through the sperm hole to the embryo sac during fertilization. It penetrates from the embryo's lead into the embryo and continues to grow in the placenta. The sperm tube contains two male gametes, one of which is attached to the ovum and the other to the nucleus. The fertilized egg cell (zygote) develops into the subject of a new plant, i.e. a diploid embryo (embryo), and the central nucleus develops into a triploid seed protein (endosperm), which the developing embryo uses for food.

A wing is the lenninel of birds and insects. Birds' wings are forelimbs. Insect wings, usually two pairs, are attached to the central body. Bats have wing-like flaps on their forelimbs. The bones of a bird's wing are light, usually hollow and reinforced with bone columns. The upper arm is short, and the visible support structure of the wing is formed by the forearm and the bones corresponding to the hand. The skeleton of the outer part of the wing, i.e. the hand wing, consists of two carpal bones and three finger bones. The bones of the hand are fused together, and they are clearly different from the corresponding bones of terrestrial mammals. A little wing attaches to the second finger bone, and the third and fourth form the tip of the wing. The ulna contains the ulna and the metatarsal bone. The bird's wings are covered with feathers and feathers. When a bird flies, the wing feathers form the bearing surface,

The floor is one of the parts of the room together with the walls and ceiling. The floor is the topmost surface structure of the load-bearing structural part – the sub-floor or intermediate floor. If the building does not have an actual sub-floor and floor structure, we speak of a "ground floor". There are several different types of floor coverings. The supporting structure is usually covered with wood (floor planks or parquet), laminate covering, tiling (clinker, stone, plastic, cork or linoleum tiling), or carpet-like covering (plastic, linoleum or textile carpet). If the surface of the load-bearing structure is in itself suitable as a floor, it can also be left uncoated, coated, or only surface treated (for example, concrete). In addition to the actual covering, the floor is often covered with loose carpets.

Glass brick is a glass square brick used in house decoration or even as small parts in structures. Glass bricks come in different colors and can have many different patterns. Glass bricks are suitable for e.g. for isolating a shower room or other room so that light still enters the room through the bricks. The light coming in and partially visible through make the glass brick a very popular interior design element. Glass bricks are sold in well-stocked hardware stores. The history of the glass brick dates back to the end of the 19th century, and it became an important element in architecture during the transition to the modernism of the early 20th century. Examples of this period are the Maison de Verre in Paris, built in 1928-1932 by architect Pierre Chareau, and the Casa del Fascio in Como, built in 1932-1936 by architect Giuseppe Terragni.

split_passages_en: Diogenes of Sinope (Greek: Διογένης), born about 412 BC. (according to the second year 404), died 323 BC, was a Greek philosopher, who was the best known representative of the Cynic school (see also Cynicism). According to tradition, Diogenes met Antisthenes when he came to Athens in exile and was impressed by his philosophy. According to the anecdotal flora, Diogenes lived on a beach in a barrel, never washed, smelled bad, was called "the dog" (Greek κύων) or even referred to himself as a dog to emphasize his ideal. The anecdote about how Alexander the Great, who had heard of the famous philosopher, visited him is well known

Diogenes of Sinope or "Diogenes the Dog" (most often just Diogenes, ) (412 BC — 323 BC) was a Greek philosopher. He represented the school of cynics. He can be considered the actual founder of the school after Antisthenes. Diogenes was born in Sinope and died in Corinth, according to Diogenes Laertius, on the same day that Alexander the Great died in Babylon. Diogenes' father was a banker. He and Diogenes were banished from Sinope on the charge of forging money, or "striking a new stamp on the coins," as the charge went. It may be that they were actually only trying to deface the already counterfeit coins so that they could not be used, thereby increasing the value of the genuine coins. Because of this, Diogenes left for Athens. He was attracted by the ascetic teaching of Antisthenes and took it up

Diogenes Laertius () (2nd century) is one of the most important biographers of philosophers who lived in antiquity. He was Greek and, based on his name, possibly from Laertes of Cilicia or from the Roman family of Laertius. Almost nothing is known about Diogenes' own life, but his preserved work "The Lives and Doctrines of Notable Philosophers" is one of the most central sources of the history of Greek philosophy. Almost nothing is known about Diogenes' life. He has been dated to the 2nd century. He must have lived after Sekstos Empericus (c. 200), for he mentions him, and before Stephen of Byzantium (c. 500), from whom the earliest quotation from him is known. Diogenes does not mention Neoplatonic philosophers, although his main work was addressed to a woman interested in Platonism. Diogenes probably lived a century

Venäjän presidentti Vladimir Putin muokkasi FSB:tä uudelleen vuoden 2004 keskivaiheilla. Vuonna 1998 Aleksandr Litvinenko ja seitsemän muuta FSB:n 1990-luvulla perustetun "tappohallinto" Urpon miestä kertoi sotilassyyttäjänvirastossa saaneensa tehtäväkseen surmata Mihail Trepaškinin. split_passages_en: The Free Software Foundation (FSF) is a non-profit organization founded by Richard Stallman in 1985 to support the GNU project and educate about the benefits of free software. From the founding of the FSF until the mid-1990s, the FSF spent most of its funds on software development. Nowadays, FSF focuses more on legal matters. The FSF board consists of 6 members.

after the coup attempt, the secret police of the Soviet Union, the KGB, was disbanded in November 1991. The most significant part of the KGB's agencies was formed into the Ministry of Security MB. Yeltsin dissolved the Ministry of Security after the 1993 constitutional crisis and replaced it with a new agency called the FSK in early 1994. The FSK was reorganized by the amended law into the FSB. In March 1997, the FSB was reformed due to a political power struggle. Russian President Vladimir Putin reshaped the FSB in mid-2004. In 1998, Aleksandr Litvinenko and seven other men from Urpo, the FSB's "assassination agency" established in the 1990s, told the military prosecutor's office that they had been assigned to kill Mikhail Trepashkin. Later, Urpo was abolished, but in 2006 the murders of terrorist suspects abroad were legalized. passage_in_language: <0> Abbasidikalifaatti (, "") oli kolmas Islamilainen kalifaatti. Sen perusti Muhammedin sedän Abbas ibn Abdul-Muttalibin (566-653) – jonka mukaan kalifaatti on nimetty – perillinen. Abbasidit hallitsivat suurinta osaa kalifaattia pääkaupungistaan Bagdadista käsin kalifeina kaadettuaan Umaijadien kalifaatin vuonna 750 päättyneessä Abbasidien vallankumouksessa. Abbasidikalifaatin hallinto keskitettiin aluksi Kufaan, mutta vuonna 762 kalifi Al-Mansur perusti Bagdadin kaupungin lähelle muinaisen Sasanian pääkaupunkia Ktesifonia. Abbasidien ajanjaksoa leimasi riippuvuus Persian byrokraattien (erityisesti Barmakid-suvun) hallitsemista alueista sekä arabimaiden ulkopuolisten muslimien lisääntyvä määrä "ummassa" (islamin uskovien yhteisö). Hallitseva eliitti omaksui laajasti persialaiset tavat ja he alkoivatkin tukemaan taiteilijoita ja oppineita. Bagdadista tuli tieteen, kulttuurin, filosofian ja keksintöjen keskus. Nykyään <1> käyttäjinä. Medinan jäätyä kauas laajentuneen valtakunnan suurista keskuksista kehitys vei vääjäämättä siihen, että valta siirtyi pohjoiseen. Ensin Umaijadit siirsivät pääkaupunkinsa Damaskokseen, joka toimi kalifaatin hallintokaupunkina 661-750, jonka jälkeen abbasidit siirsivät pääkaupungin Bagdadiin vuonna 750. Ensimmäinen umaijadikalifi Muawija I (661-680) oli vahva hallitsija ja taitava hallintomies. Hän organisoi uudelleen kaoottisen beduiiniarmeijansa, perusti islamin historian ensimmäisen keskusviraston, pani alulle postilaitoksen ja määräsi arabian valtakuntansa virkakieleksi. Kalifin valta oli perinnöllinen ja periaatteessa rajaton, mutta virkakoneiston kasvaessa abbasidikaudella syntyi ja vakiintui käytäntö, jonka mukaan kalifi delegoi valtansa visiirille ("wazir"), tuomiovaltansa ylituomarille ("qadi") ja sotilasjohdon armeijan komentajalle ("amir") säilyttäen silti kaikessa viimeisen sanan itsellään. Moni <2> Fatimidit tai fatimidien kalifaatti oli šiiamuslimien dynastia, joka hallitsi suurta osaa Pohjois-Afrikasta vuodesta 910 vuoteen 1171. Fatimidit kuuluivat nykyisin šiialaisten vähemmistöä edustavaan ismailiittien suuntaukseen. Dynastian vuonna 909 perustanut, Pohjois-Afrikkaan siirtynyt Ubayd Allah al-Mahdi Billah esitti olevansa ismailiittien kätkeytyneen imaamin, Ismail bin Jafarin perillinen ja vaati valtaa koko muslimimaailmassa. Hän sai pian haltuunsa koko Keski-Maghrebin, johon kuuluivat nykyiset Marokko, Algeria, Tunisia ja Libya. Sitä hallittiin Tunisiaan perustetusta pääkaupungista käsin. Fatimidit valloittivat Egyptin 972, siirsivät pääkaupunkinsa Kairoon ja haastoivat vakavasti sunnalaisen abbasidien kalifaatin. Fatimidien hallitseman alueen väestö ei laajassa mitassa kääntynyt ismailiiteiksi, vaan pysyi enimmäkseen sunnalaisina. Egyptissä oli myös merkittävä kristitty väestö.
split_passages_en: The Abbasid Caliphate (, "") was the third Islamic Caliphate. It was founded by the heir of Muhammad's uncle Abbas ibn Abdul-Muttalib (566-653) – after whom the caliphate is named. The Abbasids ruled most of the caliphate from their capital, Baghdad, as caliphs after overthrowing the Umayyad Caliphate in the Abbasid Revolution that ended in 750. The administration of the Abbasid Caliphate was initially centered in Kufa, but in 762 Caliph Al-Mansur founded the city of Baghdad near the ancient Sasanian capital of Ctesiphon. The Abbasid period was marked by dependence on territories controlled by Persian bureaucrats (especially the Barmakid clan) and the increasing number of non-Arab Muslims in the "umma" (community of believers in Islam). The ruling elite widely adopted Persian customs and began to support artists and scholars. Baghdad became a center of science, culture, philosophy and invention. Today

as users. After Medina was frozen far from the major centers of the expanded empire, the development inevitably led to the fact that power shifted to the north. First, the Umayyads moved their capital to Damascus, which served as the administrative city of the caliphate from 661 to 750, after which the Abbasids moved the capital to Baghdad in 750. The first Umayyad caliph, Muawiya I (661-680), was a strong ruler and a skilled administrator. He reorganized his chaotic Bedouin army, established the first central office in Islamic history, started a postal service, and made Arabic the official language of his empire. The power of the caliph was hereditary and in principle unlimited, but as the bureaucracy grew in the Abbasid period, the practice arose and became established, according to which the caliph delegated his power to the vizier ("wazir"), his judicial power to the chief judge ("qadi") and military leadership to the army commander ("amir"), still retaining the last word in everything by himself. Multi

The Fatimids, or the Fatimid Caliphate, were a Shiite Muslim dynasty that ruled much of North Africa from 910 to 1171. The Fatimids belonged to the Ismaili sect, which today represents a minority of Shiites. Ubayd Allah al-Mahdi Billah, who founded the dynasty in 909 and moved to North Africa, presented himself as the heir of the hidden Ismaili imam, Ismail bin Jafar, and claimed power in the entire Muslim world. He soon gained control of the entire Central Maghreb, which included present-day Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia and Libya. It was governed from the capital established in Tunisia. The Fatimids conquered Egypt in 972, moved their capital to Cairo, and seriously challenged the Sunni Abbasid Caliphate. The population of the area ruled by the Fatimids did not convert to Ismaili to a large extent, but remained mostly Sunni. Egypt also had a significant Christian population.

split_passages_en: Hadera () is a city in Israel in the Haifa District. The current city was founded by Jewish immigrants in 1890. At the end of 2016, the city had a population of 91,707. The current name of Hadera is derived from the Arabic name "al-Khaḍrāʾ" meaning green, which referred to the area's marshes and the algae that grew there. The earliest signs of settlement in the Hadera area come from the Chalcolithic period. Many Bronze Age discoveries have been made in the area, such as buildings, mosaics and, for example, a Roman bridge. The Crusaders called the city there Lictera, but the place was abandoned after the Crusades. The current Hadera was founded in 1890 by members of Hovevei Zion, immigrants from Vilna, Kovno and Riga. Malaria plagued the swampy area, and about half of Hadera's Jewish immigrants were the first to die

Hadeholm is a Carolingian farm which is claimed locally to have been one of Queen Kristina's many "hunting castles". Among other things, the queen gave an island, Gävan, to the Hedesunda farmers in exchange for work on the palace in Stockholm. Hadeholm is on the Dalälven in Hedesunda parish, Gävle municipality. The manor is now privately owned. The rune stone Gs 6 in Hade is the oldest written source. The runic carver Öpir is considered to have carved it. Hade is mentioned in other early written sources in 1350, 1401 and 1424. Past Hade passes the ancient trail between Uppsala - Östervåla - Hedesunda or Mälaren - Enköping / Västerås - Tärnsjö, (Nora parish), - Hedesunda. In Hade there are burial grounds from the Roman Iron Age (0-400 AD). The grave area is located with a view of the Dalälven. In the middle of the 19th century, parts of three silver-mounted bronze drinking horns from the 4th century, and five bronze robe buckles from the 6th century were found. The finds show connections with the Black Sea region and the Roman Rhine area. An iron knife, slag, spearheads, a fork, beads were also found here

Esimerkiksi kaikki erilaiset kartio­leikkaukset ovat ekvi­valentteja kompleksisessa projek­tiivisessa geo­metriassa, ja jotkut ympyröitä koskevat teoreemat voidaan käsittää näiden yleisten teoreemojen erikois­tapauksiksi. 1800-luvun alussa muun muassa Jean-Victor Poncelet'n ja Lazare Carnot'n tutkimukset tekivät projek­tiivisesta geo­metriasta itsenäisen matematiikan haaran. Sen perusteita tarkensi Karl von Staudt, ja 1800-luvun lopulla italialaiset Giuseppe Peano, Mario Pieri, Alessandro Padoa ja Gino Fano kehittivät ne täydelliseen muotoon. Affiinisen ja euklidisen geo­metrian tavoin myös projek­tiivinen geo­metria voidaan muotoilla Felix Kleinin Erlangenin ohjelman avulla: projek­tiivista geo­metriaa luonnehtivat projek­tiivisen ryhmän muunnosten invariantit. Andrei Kolmogorov kehitti todennäköisyyslaskennalle mittateoreettiset aksioomat <2> Geometria () on matematiikan ala, joka tutkii kuvioita ja kappaleita ja niiden ominaisuuksia. Vanha suomen kielen nimitys on "mittausoppi". Geometrian varhaisia merkittäviä tekstejä oli Eukleideen noin vuonna 300 eaa. kirjoittama oppikirja Alkeet. Teos koostuu 13 kirjasta, joissa käsitellään euklidista geometriaa ja aikakauden lukuteoriaa. 1600-luvun alkupuolella René Descartes ja Pierre de Fermat kehittivät analyyttisen geometrian. Venäläinen matemaatikko Nikolai Lobatševski kehitti 1800-luvun alussa epäeuklidisen geometrian, jossa euklidisen geometrian viides aksiooma ei pitänyt paikkaansa. 1800-luvun aikana geometrian edistykseen vaikuttivat myös analyysin ja differentiaaligeometrian parissa työskennellyt Bernhard Riemann ja algebrallisen topologian luoja Henri Poincaré. Babylonialaiset, egyptiläiset, intialaiset ja kiinalaiset käyttivät apunaan geometriaa jo paljon
split_passages_en: are simple sentences. For example, all different conic sections are equivalent in complex projective geometry, and some theorems about circles can be conceived as special cases of these general theorems. At the beginning of the 19th century, the researches of, among others, Jean-Victor Poncelet and Lazare Carnot made projective geometry an independent branch of mathematics. Its foundations were refined by Karl von Staudt, and at the end of the 19th century the Italians Giuseppe Peano, Mario Pieri, Alessandro Padoa and Gino Fano developed them into a perfect form. Like affine and Euclidean geometry, projective geometry can also be formulated using Felix Klein's Erlangen program: projective geometry is characterized by the invariants of transformations of the projective group. The basics of projective geometry became understood when a great many theorems had been derived from the field with the help of extensive research.

were later defined by metric sets and Borel sets. Constantin Carathéodory developed the general theory of measure theory by defining e.g. external dimension and general dimension. Alfred Haar is known for the Haar measure, which can be used to define a kind of intuitively surface/volume-like concept for locally compact topological groups. It turned out that the definitions of measure theory fit well to correspond to the geometry of complex and pathological sets. With it, it was possible to define for groups, e.g. a dimension that tells more about the fine structure of a set than, for example, a traditional topological dimension. More on this in the article Hausdorff dimension. In fact, in 1919, A.S. Besicovič developed the geometric measure theory to answer the geometric questions of sets and measures. Measure theory has been very useful in applications. The birth of measure theory revolutionized e.g. probability calculation. Andrei Kolmogorov developed measure-theoretic axioms for probability calculations

Geometry () is the branch of mathematics that studies figures and bodies and their properties. The old Finnish name is "measurement theory". Early significant texts on geometry were by Euclid around 300 BC. written textbook Alkeet. The work consists of 13 books dealing with Euclidean geometry and the number theory of the period. In the early 17th century, René Descartes and Pierre de Fermat developed analytic geometry. At the beginning of the 19th century, the Russian mathematician Nikolai Lobachevsky developed a non-Euclidean geometry in which the Fifth Axiom of Euclidean geometry did not hold. During the 19th century, the progress of geometry was also influenced by Bernhard Riemann, who worked on analysis and differential geometry, and Henri Poincaré, the creator of algebraic topology. The Babylonians, Egyptians, Indians and Chinese already used geometry a lot

split_passages_en: The first touches to the sport took place already in the first decade of the 20th century, when, for example, members of the temperance association Koito played a game similar to basketball in Helsinki's Hakasalmi park. In the game, the ball was thrown into a closed basket, from which it was taken out with a stick or a puck. From the capital, the sport began to spread to other parts of Finland, and in 1917 and 1918, a similar game was played in Kotka. In 1922, members of the Finnish Workers' Sports Association made a trip to the Soviet Union, where the sport was already played more. Among the travelers, there was a desire to bring the sport to Finland as well, and the purpose was to include basketball in the sports programs. However, the lack of halls in Finland and the lack of enthusiasm put a damper on the dreams of this. Korisliiga is the main league of men's basketball in Finland. The men's main series has been played under the name Korisliiga since the 2005–2006 season. In the 2004–2005 season, the series was called Sparliiga according to its main sponsor. In the seasons 1999–2004, the series was played under the name SM-koris, and before this, the series was called the men's basketball SM series. The men's basketball Finnish championship has been played since 1939, when the championship was won by the Ylioppilaskorpalloilijat from Helsinki. The Panthers have won the most Finnish championships (14 in total). According to an article published by Urheilusanomat in January 2015, Korisliiga is the 15th best national league in Europe. In the spring of 1939, the Finnish Basketball Federation assembled an indoor league of twelve teams to compete for the Finnish men's basketball championship for the first time. Helsinki NMKY, who played in the SKL series, won the Finnish championship by defeating TUL's champion Työväen Maila-Pojat in the final. In June 2015, the Finnish Basketball Association and Elisa announced a 3+1-year cooperation agreement, according to which the Elisa Viihde service will broadcast all regular season and playoff games of the Basketball League worldwide. Watching matches on mobile devices is also possible. The broadcast technology uses automatic cameras installed in the arenas in the previous season. In October 2014, Korisliiga and clubs started a three-year project to broadcast all Korisliiga matches live via KorisliigaTV. The matches could be watched all over the world. split_passages_en: Aisha bint Abu Bakr (, "she who lives", other spellings A'ishah, Ayesha, A'isha and Aisha, 613 or 614 Mecca – July 678 Medina) was the third wife of the Islamic prophet Muhammad. She is sometimes called Muhammad's favorite wife. In Islamic writings, she is often referred to by the title "Mother of the Believers" (), according to the description in the Qur'an (33:6), where Muhammad's wives are called "mothers of the believers". Many hadiths, or traditions about the life of the Prophet Muhammad, are written in Aisha's name. Aisha's father Abu Bakr was one of Muhammad's most important supporters even before Aisha's union with Muhammad. Within Islam, there are different ideas about the engagement of Aisha and Muhammad, because the Koran does not say anything about it. Interpretations are derived from hadiths whose reliability

Sudden respiratory distress syndrome or adult respiratory distress syndrome or ARDS () refers to a sudden lung injury that results in severe oxygenation disorder. ARDS is usually caused by an underlying disease that directly damages the lungs, such as pneumonia. Sometimes ARDS can arise indirectly through the body's strong inflammatory response, for example in sepsis, pancreatitis or a lung burn. The mechanism of ARDS is extensive damage to the walls of alveoli and pulmonary capillaries. The syndrome begins with an exudative phase lasting a few days, when fluid seeps from the damaged blood vessels into the lung tissue and causes pulmonary edema. After that, exudates are organized and alveolar cells proliferate in a proliferative phase lasting a few weeks. Eventually, lung damage progresses to pulmonary fibrosis, i.e. connective tissue formation and scarring of the lungs. ARDS leads to pulmonary edema, difficulty in blood oxygenation, increase in blood pressure, increase in pulmonary circulation resistance

The AIS classification () is a severity classification developed in the United States, especially for the classification of injuries caused in traffic accidents. The AIS classifies each injury in a different area of ​​the body (9) based on severity on a 6-point scale, where 1 is mild and 6 is fatal. In the AIS code, the first six digits indicate the location and type of injury, and the number after the dot indicates the severity of the injury. For example, the number series 441438.5 means unilateral contusion of the lung with tension pneumothorax, and the injury is classified as critical in severity.

This disrupts or completely prevents the development of male characteristics and male genitalia from the fetal stage in a person with AIS. split_passages_en: "Evako laulu" is a piece of music composed and written by Veikko Lavi, which tells the story of a Karelian emigrant's wartime evacuation trip to Finland from the point of view of a small child. The song begins with the words "In the evening when my mother covered me to sleep, I had no idea what the morning would bring...". The song is especially well known as a recording by Anneli Saaristo from 1985. The recording was arranged by Upi Sorvali. The touching song has become a significant interpreter of emotions among people of Karelian descent, along with the folk song "Karjalan kunnai". The theme for the song was given to Lavi by his long-time accompanist Pertti Husu, who once told Lavi his evacuee story on a concert trip. "Evako's song" was first performed by Veikko Tuomi in Pori, but it became known as Anneli Saariston's version. During the recording of the song, Saariston had a hard time holding back his tears.

Evald is a Germanic male first name of origin. It is formed from the Germanic words "e" meaning "law" and "order" and "wald" meaning "ruling". The name was popularized by two Anglo-Saxon missionaries who lived at the end of the 7th century, the so-called White and Black Evald, who operated in Germany in the Rhine region and were martyred there. Their memorial day is October 3, which is also Evald's name day according to the Finnish-Swedish calendar. In Finland, the name Evald was given to 2,074 people from the beginning of the 20th century until the end of 2009, and Ewald to 60 people, according to the data of the Population Register Center.

split_passages_en: In Greek mythology, the Argo () was the ship on which Jason and the Argonauts sailed to Colchis to rob a golden ram's pulley guarded by a dragon. The Argos was built by Argos, son of Phrixus, from an oak tree that grew at the oracle site of Dodona, and so the ship could speak and prophesy. Argo also served as an inspiration when Ptolemy created a constellation representing it in the southern starry sky, the ship Argo. According to the "Odyssey", the Argo was the first ship to make it past Scylla and Kharybdis unscathed.

The Dido class was a class of anti-aircraft cruisers of the British Royal Navy consisting of sixteen ships, six of which were discontinued due to perceived modification needs. Of these six, however, "HMS Argonaut" was already too far built, and its modifications were cancelled. In this way, two subclasses were born in the class: the Dido class and the Bellona class, i.e. the improved Dido class. The actual Dido class consisted of eleven ships. The ships of the class were equipped with semi-automatic 5.25-inch cannons. Installations equipped with a power transmission made it possible to use an elevation angle of up to 70 degrees. The slow delivery of new gun turrets caused the diversity of the main armament of the ships. The side armor of the ships was 3-inch and the deck was 1-inch at the engine rooms. The rudder was also protected by one-inch armor. The ammunition stores were protected by 2-inch deck armor. The wall thickness of the turrets was 0.5 inches.

The Argonauts (, singular, "Argonautēs") were a group of heroes in Greek mythology, especially known for their "Argonaut expedition" on the ship Argo before the Trojan War. Iason and his companions traveled on a ship built by Argos to Colchiene to retrieve the golden pulley of the winged ram, which was guarded by a sleepless dragon. There were fifty Argonauts. They include Asklepios, Herakles, Autolykos, Kastor, Polydeukes, Theseus, Amphion, Meleagros, Augeias, Laocoon, Nestor, Ankaios, Iolaus and Achilles' father Peleus. The legend of the Argonauts is best known from Apollonios Rhodoslaisen's extensive poem "Argonautika". According to the legend, Jason, the young son of a Thessalian prince, came to greet Pelias, who had usurped his father's kingdom. In order to get rid of the young man, Pelias persuaded him to go to Colchiene on the eastern shore of the Black Sea to retrieve the golden pulley from there. Orkhomenos

The ship Argo (also Argo, ) is an old constellation that Ptolemy named in his group of 48 constellations. Its prototype is the Argo of Greek mythology, which was the ship used by Jason and the Argonauts. Argo is not among the 88 constellations in use today, as in 1763 the French astronomer Nicolas Louis de Lacaille split it into Köl ("Carina"), Stern ("Puppis") and Sail ("Vela"). While Argo was broken up, its stars were divided into different constellations: Argo's α and β stars remained in the Köl, γ and δ in the Sail, ε in the Köl, and ζ in the Bow. Argo was probably broken up by Lacaille due to the constellation's enormous size. The constellation created by Lacaille called Kompassi ("Pyxis") is not related to the traditional Argo, though

split_passages_en: Mannerheim's statue is a bronze statue of C. G. E. Mannerheim, about three meters high, made by sculptor Evert Porila, located in Leinola, Tampere. The sculpture was made in 1939, but the statue was erected only in 1956. It was made according to a painting by Eero Järnefelt and is located eight kilometers from the city center on the Mannerheiminkalli in Leinola, from where Mannerheim is said to have watched the capture of Tampere during the Finnish Civil War in 1918. The initiative for the statue project was taken by trade advisor Rafael Haarla just before his death. The statue was commissioned from the sculptor by the Rintamamiesyhdistys of the Tampere region, which represented the freedom fighters, i.e. the white side of the civil war. The finished sculpture was supposed to be unveiled at the beginning of 1940, but the winter war postponed the unveiling. The largest bodies organizing psychedelic studies are the Multidisciplinary Association for Psychedelic Studies (MAPS), the Beckley Foundation and the Heffter Research Institute. Psychedelics are many plants and artificial compounds that cause similar changes in the normal functioning of consciousness. The psychedelic experience varies in quality and intensity depending on the substance, which is why the delimitation of the group of psychedelics is not clear-cut. The effect of psychedelics also depends a lot on the user's own state of mind and the circumstances in which the use takes place. The state of mind includes, for example, the user's attitudes, preparation, interests and feelings towards the substance and other people present. Circumstances include time of day, weather, music and other environmental factors. In a controlled research situation, the aim is to make the room

psychedelics. They are derivatives of 2C compounds and thus also of phenethylamine. The 2-NB group includes e.g. 25I-NBOMe and 25C-NBOMe. Most known psychedelics are semi-synthetically produced using precursors found in nature. For example, LSD can be made from ergotamine from buckwheat. Psychedelics that occur in nature are e.g. psilocybin (e.g. wormwood), mescaline (e.g. mescaline cactus), DMT (e.g. "Mimosa tenuiflora" and the ayahuasca made from it). Psychedelics can cause mystical experiences. When psychedelics are used for religious or spiritual purposes, they can be called entheogens. According to some researchers, entheogens may have had a significant influence on the birth of religions. Well-known examples of the use of indigenous entheogens include the use of the red fly agaric mushroom among Siberian shamans (and possibly as an active ingredient in the soma described in the Hindu Rigveda) and the psilocybin mushrooms of the Mexican Indians

Psychedelics are compounds that cause altered states of consciousness such as hallucinations, mystical experiences, hallucinations, strong emotional states and the surfacing of memories. They act like neurotransmitters and activate receptors on the surface of nerve cells. The most well-known psychedelics are, for example, LSD, psilocin, mescaline, LSA and DMT. The use of most psychedelics is prohibited in much of the world, except for licensed use in religious ceremonies, therapy or scientific research, for example. In medicine, psychedelics have been used, for example, as a treatment for addictions. Psychedelics are often defined pharmacologically as part of a wider group of hallucinogens, which also includes dissociatives and deliriums. The term "psychedelic" was coined in 1956 by psychedelic researcher Humphry Osmond. He combined the Greek words "psyche", "soul, mind" and "delein", "express".
